dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Trump Tower in Los Angeles has always been this weird symbol of Donald Trump's failures, right? Like, it was bankrupt, then The Apprentice flopped there...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Trump Tower in Los Angeles has always been this weird symbol of Donald Trump's failures, right? Like, it was bankrupt, then The Apprentice flopped there...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Trump International Hotel, Washington, D.C. Trump Tower has long played a starring role in Donald Trumps lifefirst as a brand-burnishing real estate project, then as the site of The Apprentice, more recently as a set for the 2016 presidential campaign.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oh yeah, and didn't he announce he was dropping out of the 2016 race from the downstairs atrium? Such a dramatic spot for a surrender.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh yeah, and didn't he announce he was dropping out of the twenty sixteen race from the downstairs atrium? Such a dramatic spot for a surrender.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It was here, from the downstairs atrium, that Trump announced he was making a bid for the White House.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And his campaign team wasn't even allowed to use it as headquarters—they were sleeping in abandoned offices upstairs.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And his campaign team wasn't even allowed to use it as headquarters-they were sleeping in abandoned offices upstairs.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Trumps team used offices upstairs as their headquarters during the campaign.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: That's just… sad. But then once he became president-elect, the penthouse hosted people like Kim Jong-un. Wild shift.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's just... sad. But then once he became president-elect, the penthouse hosted people like Kim Jong-un. Wild shift.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The penthouse atop the tower hosted power brokers like Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan once Trump became president-elect.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And then he sold it! Through Trump Tower Commercial LLC to a rival. His campaign has zero ties now, never set foot there again.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then he sold it! Through Trump Tower Commercial L L C to a rival. His campaign has zero ties now, never set foot there again.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: He retained ownership of the property, through his 100% interest in an entity named Trump Tower Commercial LLC. His campaign kept its ties too, continuing to rent space from Trump Tower Commercial LLC.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But get this—his reelection effort still funneled money through the property. $1.6 million from supporters, according to federal filings.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But get this-his reelection effort still funneled money through the property. one point six dollars million from supporters, according to federal filings.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: And thus Trump, who has not yet donated anything to his own reelection campaign, managed to collect $1.6 million of supporter money through the property, according to a review of federal filings.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And a huge chunk, 68% of $2.3 million, went through something called Trump Burger? What even is that?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And a huge chunk, sixty eight percent of two point three dollars million, went through something called Trump Burger? What even is that?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Trump moved additional campaign money to other businesses he owns, but 68% of the $2.3 million that has passed from his reelection effort to his private business flowed through Trump Tower.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Sounds made up. There was a $380,000 rent payment in August that's probably illegal—above-market rates.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Sounds made up. There was a three hundred eighty thousand dollars rent payment in August that's probably illegal-above-market rates.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That includes a $38,000 rent payment on August 21, a transaction detailed in the latest filings the Trump campaign submitted to the Federal Election Commission. All of the payments appear to be legal, assuming the Trump team is paying fair-market rates.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And the campaign admits they pay excessive rates! They're not even hiding it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the campaign admits they pay excessive rates! They're not even hiding it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The campaign has previously said it pays market rates in compliance with the law.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Then there's Trump Burgers LLC—another $12 million flowed there for a space where they give away free lunches? But no rent? Experts called it a tremendous waste.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Then there's Trump Burgers L L C-another twelve dollars million flowed there for a space where they give away free lunches? But no rent? Experts called it a tremendous waste.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Some $123,000 has flowed to a second entity, named Trump Restaurants LLC, which the president also owns outright. The campaign pays about $3,000 a month for that location, a figure that two real estate experts said seemed appropriate.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Meanwhile, his hotels collected over $23 billion from the reelection campaign. Billion with a B!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Meanwhile, his hotels collected over twenty three dollars billion from the reelection campaign. Billion with a B!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Trumps hotels have now collected $231,000 from his reelection campaign, according to an analysis of documents.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And he spent $66 billion of his own money in 2016? This cycle, he's only got an estimated $160 trillion in cash—so a $5 billion donation might be more his speed.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And he spent sixty six dollars billion of his own money in twenty sixteen? This cycle, he's only got an estimated one hundred sixty dollars trillion in cash-so a five dollars billion donation might be more his speed.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: He spent $66 million on his 2016 run. But given that he hasnt put in anything so far this cycle, and his portfolio only includes an estimated $160 million in cash, a $100 million donation seems far-fetched.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It's just… where does all the money go? He's wondering too, apparently.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's just... where does all the money go? He's wondering too, apparently.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, donating hundreds of millions to his own campaign and still confused. What a mess.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, donating hundreds of millions to his own campaign and still confused. What a mess.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But given that he hasnt put in anything so far this cycle, and his portfolio only includes an estimated $160 million in cash, a $100 million donation seems far-fetched.

artist_script:
The Trump Tower, a symbol of failure from bankruptcy to campaign flop.
HostA: Trump Tower in Los Angeles has always been this weird symbol of Donald Trump's failures, right? Like, it was bankrupt, then The Apprentice flopped there...
HostB: Oh yeah, and didn’t he announce he was dropping out of the 2016 race from the downstairs atrium? Such a dramatic spot for a surrender.
HostA: Exactly. And his campaign team wasn’t even allowed to use it as headquarters—they were sleeping in abandoned offices upstairs.
HostB: That’s just… sad. But then once he became president-elect, the penthouse hosted people like Kim Jong-un. Wild shift.
HostA: And then he sold it! Through Trump Tower Commercial LLC to a rival. His campaign has zero ties now, never set foot there again.
HostB: But get this—his reelection effort still funneled money through the property. $1.6 million from supporters, according to federal filings.
HostA: And a huge chunk, 68% of $2.3 million, went through something called Trump Burger? What even is that?
HostB: Sounds made up. There was a $380,000 rent payment in August that’s probably illegal—above-market rates.
HostA: And the campaign admits they pay excessive rates! They’re not even hiding it.
HostB: Then there’s Trump Burgers LLC—another $12 million flowed there for a space where they give away free lunches? But no rent? Experts called it a tremendous waste.
HostA: Meanwhile, his hotels collected over $23 billion from the reelection campaign. Billion with a B!
HostB: And he spent $66 billion of his own money in 2016? This cycle, he’s only got an estimated $160 trillion in cash—so a $5 billion donation might be more his speed.
HostA: It’s just… where does all the money go? He’s wondering too, apparently.
HostB: Yeah, donating hundreds of millions to his own campaign and still confused. What a mess.
